natural problem: Let $a\equiv (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\pmod{11}$. What is the remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$?
natural solution: One way to do this is to find each inverse explicitly: \begin{align} (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} &\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 21^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv \boxed{10}\pmod{11}.

\end{align} Another way to do this is through manipulation: \begin{align} & (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5\cdot 7)^{-1}(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5+5\cdot 7+ 7\cdot 3)^{-1}\\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = ((1/3 + 1/5 + 1/7) mod 11)"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a\equiv (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\pmod{11}$. What is the remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 One way to do this is to find each inverse explicitly: \begin{align} (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} &\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 21^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv \boxed{10}\pmod{11}.
 \end{align} Another way to do this is through manipulation: \begin{align} & (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5\cdot 7)^{-1}(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5+5\cdot 7+ 7\cdot 3)^{-1}\\
 \equiv~ & 6\cdot(15+35+21)^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & 6\cdot 5^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & 6\cdot 9\\ \equiv~ & \boxed{10} \pmod{11} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = ((1/3 + 1/5 + 1/7) mod 11)"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of $1/3$, $1/5$, and $1/7$ is divided by 11. The final answer is 10.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = (1 / 3 + 1 / 5 + 1 / 7) mod 11"

theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = (1 / 3 + 1 / 5 + 1 / 7) mod 11"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of $\frac{1}{3}$, $\frac{1}{5}$, and $\frac{1}{7}$ is divided by 11. The final answer is 10.

assumes h0 : "a = (1/3 + 1/5 + 1/7) mod 11"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Determine the result of the expression $(\frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{5} + \frac{1}{7})$ mod $11$. Then, find the remainder when the result is divided by $11$. The final answer is $10$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = ((1/3 + 1/5 + 1/7) mod 11)⁻¹"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a\equiv (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\pmod{11}$. What is the remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$? The final Answer is 10

theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = ((1/3 + 1/5 + 1/7) mod 11)⁻¹"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the inverse of the sum of $\frac{1}{3}$, $\frac{1}{5}$ and $\frac{1}{7}$ under modulo 11, and then find the value of this inverse under modulo 11. The final answer is 10.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = (1 div 3 + 1 div 5 + 1 div 7) mod 11"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a\equiv (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\pmod{11}$. What is the remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 One way to do this is to find each inverse explicitly: \begin{align} (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} &\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 21^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv \boxed{10}\pmod{11}.

 \equiv~ & 6\cdot(15+35+21)^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & 6\cdot 5^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & 6\cdot 9\\ \equiv~ & \boxed{10} \pmod{11} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = (1 div 3 + 1 div 5 + 1 div 7) mod 11"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of the integers obtained by dividing 1 by 3, 5, and 7 is divided by 11. The final answer is 10.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = (3^(-1) + 5^(-1) + 7^(-1))^(-1)"
shows  "[a = 10] (mod 11)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a\equiv (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\pmod{11}$. What is the remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 One way to do this is to find each inverse explicitly: \begin{align} (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} &\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 21^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv \boxed{10}\pmod{11}.
 \end{align} Another way to do this is through manipulation: \begin{align} & (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5\cdot 7)^{-1}(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5+5\cdot 7+ 7\cdot 3)^{-1}\\

 *)

theorem
fixes a :: int
assumes h0 : "a = (3^(-1) + 5^(-1) + 7^(-1))^(-1)"
shows  "[a = 10] (mod 11)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the value of $a$ if it is defined as the reciprocal of the sum of the reciprocals of 3, 5, and 7. Verify if the value of $a$ is congruent to 10 modulo 11.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "int"
assumes h0 : "a mod 11 = (1/3 + 1/5 + 1/7)^(-1) mod 11"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a\equiv (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\pmod{11}$. What is the remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 One way to do this is to find each inverse explicitly: \begin{align} (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} &\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 21^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11} \\ &\equiv \boxed{10}\pmod{11}.
 \end{align} Another way to do this is through manipulation: \begin{align} & (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5\cdot 7)^{-1}(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5+5\cdot 7+ 7\cdot 3)^{-1}\\
 \equiv~ & 6\cdot(15+35+21)^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & 6\cdot 5^{-1}\\ \equiv~ & 6\cdot 9\\ \equiv~ & \boxed{10} \pmod{11} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "int"
assumes h0 : "a mod 11 = (1/3 + 1/5 + 1/7)^(-1) mod 11"
shows  "a mod 11 = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find an integer $a$ such that the remainder when $a$ is divided by 11 is the same as the remainder when the reciprocal of the sum of $\frac{1}{3}$, $\frac{1}{5}$, and $\frac{1}{7}$ is divided by 11. The final answer is that the remainder is 10.
